You ask a question "Let us make an assumption, that known natural laws are not valid. What would happen according to these laws, if something...". If other words, it is not reasonable at all. Theory of relativity predicts that no interaction can accelerate body with mass to a light speed. Therefore it can not predict what would happen, if it was not right.

KSP does not take relativistic effects into account. Light speed has no meaning in the game. But physics model have some assumption of velocities when it calculates the positions of planets and solves the equation of motion and if you give insane velocity to a planet or a spacecraft, results are insane, as you see.

Speed of light is the same for everyone, everywhere. standard analogy is that if a car light travelling at the speed of light turns its lights on how fast is the light from the headlight travelling. (Answer, the speed of light not the speed of light x2) As you said, the speed of sound is relative to the medium it is travelling through, not how fast the emitter is travelling. This is the same for light travelling through space.

I have assumed here that you mean orbital speed as the speed of light, if rotation became the speed of light the earth would shed all of its mass (at least it will make space launches cheap)

You have assumed in your experiment that the speed of light is the same in the kerbal universe. There is no reason for this to be the case, it could be slower or faster.
